news_summary: Recent technological advancements are enhancing everyday life through innovative approaches like extending fruit freshness using ozone treatment and revealing hidden images with advanced flat chip designs utilizing twisted light. Breakthroughs in material science show that broken crystals can exhibit greater strength, while new insights into eye contact reveal its subtle yet powerful effects. Additionally, Google’s use of billions of mobile phones to detect earthquakes demonstrates the growing impact of large-scale data integration for real-time global alerts.
news_summary_fr: Les récentes avancées technologiques améliorent la vie quotidienne grâce à des approches innovantes telles que la prolongation de la fraîcheur des fruits grâce au traitement à l'ozone et la révélation d'images cachées grâce à des conceptions avancées de puces plates utilisant la lumière torsadée. Les percées dans le domaine de la science des matériaux montrent que les cristaux brisés peuvent être plus résistants, tandis que de nouvelles connaissances sur le contact visuel révèlent ses effets subtils mais puissants. En outre, l'utilisation par Google de milliards de téléphones portables pour détecter les tremblements de terre démontre l'impact croissant de l'intégration de données à grande échelle pour les alertes mondiales en temps réel.
news_summary_es: Los últimos avances tecnológicos están mejorando la vida cotidiana con enfoques innovadores como la prolongación de la frescura de la fruta mediante el tratamiento con ozono y la revelación de imágenes ocultas con diseños avanzados de chips planos que utilizan luz trenzada. Los avances en la ciencia de los materiales demuestran que los cristales rotos pueden mostrar una mayor resistencia, mientras que los nuevos conocimientos sobre el contacto visual revelan sus efectos sutiles pero poderosos. Además, el uso por Google de miles de millones de teléfonos móviles para detectar terremotos demuestra el creciente impacto de la integración de datos a gran escala para alertas mundiales en tiempo real.

articles.title: This 10-minute ozone hack keeps mangoes fresh for 28 days
articles.summary: Mango lovers and growers alike may soon rejoice: scientists at Edith Cowan University have found that a simple dip in ozonated water can drastically extend the shelf life of mangoes by up to two weeks while reducing spoilage. This technique, called aqueous ozonation, helps prevent chilling injuries that typically occur during cold storage, a long-standing challenge in mango preservation.
articles.content:
In good news for mango lovers, new research from Edith Cowan University (ECU) has identified a way to extend the storage life of the popular tropical fruit.

The study, led by ECU School of Science Lecturer Dr Mekhala Vithana, found that dipping mangoes in ozonated water (aqueous ozonation) for 10 minutes before cold storage extended the cold storage life by up to two weeks, with significantly lowered occurrence of chilling injury.

"Increasing storage life of mangoes is incredibly important for both growers and traders, as it reduces food loss during storage and offers a longer market window," Dr Vithana said.

Rise in popularity and consequential waste

With a global rise in the consumption of fruit and vegetables in recent years, there has been a subsequent increase in the production of mangoes.

However, a significant proportion is lost along the supply chain due to rapid ripening and excessive perishability.

"It is estimated that about 20 per cent of the total Australian mango production is lost or wasted, and horticultural produce is responsible for about 50 per cent of the total food waste in Australia," Dr Vithana said.

"Therefore, it is important to explore eco-friendly and cost-effective technologies to minimize post-harvest losses of mangoes."

Growers to traders

Typically, mangoes are picked at the mature green stage and stored at 13 degrees Celsius for up to 14 days, however this is not cold enough for extended storage.

"Being a tropical fruit, unripe mangoes should not be stored below 12.5 degrees due to their high sensitivity to cold temperatures," Dr Vithana said. "Prolonged storage of mango below this temperature causes a physiological disorder known as chilling injury, which damages the fruit skin and leads to decreased marketability and significant food waste.

"Therefore, susceptibility to chilling injury is the key limitation for exploiting cold storage technology to its maximum capacity for lengthening the storage life of mangoes."

Ripe for research

The study -- carried out on Australia's most widely produced variety of mango Kensington Pride -- tested aqueous ozonation technology to improve chilling tolerance during cold storage.

By dipping the mango in the ozonated water for 10 minutes prior to cold storage at 5 degrees Celsius, researchers found that they could keep the mangoes for longer with much less chilling injury.

"Generally, Kensington Pride mango can only be stored for about two weeks without ripening at 13 degrees. However, aqueous ozonation extends the storage and shelf life of these mangoes up to 28 days, with 40 per cent less chilling injury than untreated mangoes," Dr Vithana said.

"The aqueous ozonation seems to be highly feasible technology for improving chilling tolerance and quality of Kensington Pride mango fruit."

Dr Vithana said ozonation can be controlled on-site, is cost-effective and considered safe for workers at a threshold level due to its faster break down into oxygen.

"Aqueous ozonation is bubbling ozone into water through an ozone generator," she said. "Ozone is a compound widely used to sanitize fruits and vegetables on a commercial scale.

"The ozonation can be combined with the hydrocooling step after quarantine heat treatment in export mangoes or separately as a sanitization step just after harvesting, depending upon the convenience of the grower, but this needs further optimization under commercial settings."

Dr Vithana said ECU researchers are hoping to do further research on other varieties of mangoes to test their responsiveness and to achieve further reduction in chilling injury for extended cold storage.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a scientific breakthrough in food preservation technology that significantly extends the shelf life of mangoes, reducing food waste and benefiting growers, traders, and consumers. This advancement is eco-friendly, cost-effective, and has potential for broader application, which is positive and hopeful news.
articles.personality_title: This 10-minute ozone hack keeps mangoes fresh for 28 days
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Mangoes are a delicious tropical fruit enjoyed by many, but they don’t stay fresh for long. When stored in the cold, mangoes often suffer from chilling injury, which makes them spoil faster and reduces their quality.

**What happened**
Scientists at Edith Cowan University discovered that dipping mangoes in ozonated water for just 10 minutes before putting them in cold storage can extend their freshness by up to two weeks. This simple step helps prevent the chilling injuries that usually cause spoilage.

**Impact**
This discovery means mangoes can stay fresh for up to 28 days, cutting down on waste and helping growers, sellers, and buyers enjoy better fruit for longer. It’s a cost-effective and environmentally friendly method that could make a big difference in the mango supply chain.

**What's next step**
The research team will likely explore how this ozone treatment can be applied on a larger scale and whether it works for other fruits too. The goal is to bring this easy, eco-friendly preservation method to farmers and markets worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A quick 10-minute ozone water dip can keep mangoes fresh and tasty for nearly a month, reducing waste and benefiting everyone from growers to fruit lovers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Ce piratage d'ozone de 10 minutes maintient les mangues fraîches pendant 28 jours
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les mangues sont un délicieux fruit tropical apprécié par beaucoup, mais ils ne restent pas frais pendant longtemps. Lorsqu'elles sont stockées dans le froid, les mangues souffrent souvent de blessures effrayantes, ce qui les fait gâcher plus rapidement et réduit leur qualité.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les scientifiques de l'Université Edith Cowan ont découvert que tremper les mangues dans de l'eau ozonée pendant seulement 10 minutes avant de les mettre dans un stockage froid peut prolonger leur fraîcheur jusqu'à deux semaines. Cette étape simple aide à prévenir les blessures de refroidissement qui provoquent généralement une détérioration.

**Impact**
Cette découverte signifie que les mangues peuvent rester fraîches jusqu'à 28 jours, réduire les déchets et aider les producteurs, les vendeurs et les acheteurs profitent de meilleurs fruits plus longtemps. C'est une méthode rentable et respectueuse de l'environnement qui pourrait faire une grande différence dans la chaîne d'approvisionnement de la mangue.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
L'équipe de recherche explorera probablement comment ce traitement d'ozone peut être appliqué à plus grande échelle et si cela fonctionne également pour d'autres fruits. L'objectif est d'apporter cette méthode de préservation facile et respectueuse de l'environnement aux agriculteurs et aux marchés du monde entier.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Une baisse rapide de l'eau d'ozone de 10 minutes peut garder les mangues fraîches et savoureuses pendant près d'un mois, réduisant les déchets et bénéficiant à tout le monde des producteurs aux amateurs de fruits.
articles.personality_title_es: Este truco de ozono de 10 minutos mantiene los mangos frescos durante 28 días
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los mangos son una deliciosa fruta tropical que disfrutan muchos, pero no se mantienen frescos por mucho tiempo. Cuando se almacenan en el frío, los mangos a menudo sufren de lesiones escalofriantes, lo que los hace estropear más rápido y reduce su calidad.

**Qué pasó**
Los científicos de la Universidad de Edith Cowan descubrieron que sumergir los mangos en agua ozonada durante solo 10 minutos antes de ponerlos en almacenamiento en frío puede extender su frescura hasta dos semanas. Este simple paso ayuda a prevenir las lesiones de enfriamiento que generalmente causan deterioro.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento significa que los mangos pueden permanecer frescos por hasta 28 días, reduciendo los desechos y ayudando a los productores, vendedores y compradores disfrutando de una mejor fruta por más tiempo. Es un método rentable y ecológico que podría marcar una gran diferencia en la cadena de suministro de mango.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Es probable que el equipo de investigación explore cómo este tratamiento de ozono se puede aplicar a mayor escala y si también funciona para otras frutas. El objetivo es llevar este método de preservación fácil y ecológico a los agricultores y mercados de todo el mundo.

**Control de una oración**
Una salsa rápida de agua de ozono de 10 minutos puede mantener los mangos frescos y sabrosos durante casi un mes, reduciendo los desechos y beneficiando a todos, desde productores hasta amantes de la fruta.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of ripe Kensington Pride mangoes gently submerged in softly bubbling, clear ozonated water inside a simple wooden crate, surrounded by subtle cool blue and green hues symbolizing cold storage, with faint glowing outlines suggesting extended freshness and protection, set against a calm, neutral background.

articles.title: This flat chip uses twisted light to reveal hidden images
articles.summary: Using advanced metasurfaces, researchers can now twist light to uncover hidden images and detect molecular handedness, potentially revolutionizing data encryption, biosensing, and drug safety.
articles.content:
Imagine trying to wear a left-handed glove on your right hand: it doesn't fit because left and right hands are mirror images that can't be superimposed on each other. This 'handedness' is what scientists call chirality, and it plays a fundamental role in biology, chemistry, and materials science. Most DNA molecules and sugars are right-handed, while most amino acids are left-handed. Reversing a molecule's handedness can render a nutrient useless or a drug inactive and even harmful.

Light can also be left or right 'handed'. When a light beam is circularly polarized, its electric field corkscrews through space in either a left-handed or right-handed spiral. Because chiral structures interact differently with these two types of twisted light beams, shining a circularly polarized light on a sample - and comparing how much of each twist is absorbed, reflected, or delayed - lets scientists read out the sample's own handedness. However, this effect is extremely weak, which makes precise control of chirality an essential but challenging task.

Now, scientists from the Bionanophotonic Systems Laboratory in EPFL's School of Engineering have collaborated with those in Australia to create artificial optical structures called metasurfaces: 2D lattices composed of tiny elements (meta-atoms) that can easily tune their chiral properties. By varying the orientation of meta-atoms within a lattice, scientists can control the resulting metasurface's interaction with polarized light.

"Our 'chiral design toolkit' is elegantly simple, and yet more powerful than previous approaches, which tried to control light through very complex meta-atom geometries. Instead, we leverage the interplay between the shape of the meta-atom and the symmetry of the metasurface lattice," explains Bionanophotonics Lab head Hatice Altug.

The innovation, which has potential applications in data encryption, biosensing, and quantum technologies, has been published in Nature Communications.

An invisible, dual layer watermark

The team's metasurface, made of germanium and calcium difloride, presents a gradient of meta-atoms with orientations that vary continuously along a chip. The shape and angles of these meta-atoms, as well as the lattice symmetry, all work together to tune the response of the metasurface to polarized light.

In a proof-of-concept experiment, the scientists encoded two different images simultaneously on a metasurface optimized for the invisible mid-infrared range of the electromagnetic spectrum. For the first image of an Australian cockatoo, the image data were encoded in the size of the meta-atoms - which represented pixels - and decoded with unpolarized light. The second image was encoded using the orientation of the meta-atoms so that, when exposed to circularly polarized light, the metasurface revealed a picture of the iconic Swiss Matterhorn.

"This experiment showcased our technique's ability to produce a dual layer 'watermark' invisible to the human eye, paving the way for advanced anticounterfeiting, camouflage and security applications," says Bionanophotonics Systems Lab researcher Ivan Sinev.

Beyond encryption, the team's approach has potential applications for quantum technologies, many of which rely on polarized light to perform computations. The ability to map chiral responses across large surfaces could also streamline biosensing.

"We can use chiral metastructures like ours to sense, for example, drug composition or purity from small-volume samples. Nature is chiral, and the ability to distinguish between left- and right-handed molecules is essential, as it could make the difference between a medicine and a toxin," says Bionanophotonic Systems Lab researcher Felix Richter.
articles.reasoning: This article describes a significant scientific and technological breakthrough involving metasurfaces that can manipulate twisted light to reveal hidden images and detect molecular handedness. The innovation has promising applications in data encryption, biosensing, drug safety, and quantum technologies, all of which have positive implications for health, security, and scientific progress.
articles.personality_title: Flat chip twists light to reveal hidden images and protect health
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long studied 'handedness' or chirality, which means that some things, like our hands or certain molecules, come in mirror-image forms that can't be swapped. This matters a lot in biology and medicine because the right or left version of a molecule can change how it works in our bodies.

**What happened**
Researchers created a new flat chip using a special surface called a metasurface that can twist light in unique ways. This twisted light helps reveal images hidden from normal view and can detect the handedness of molecules — telling if they're left- or right-handed.

**Impact**
This breakthrough could make data encryption much safer by hiding information in twisted light patterns. It also opens the door to better biosensors that quickly identify molecules’ handedness, improving drug safety and helping ensure medicines work as intended.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to refine this technology to make it practical for everyday use in healthcare and security fields. They hope to develop devices that can easily detect molecular handedness and protect sensitive information using twisted light.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A new flat chip that twists light is unlocking hidden images and molecular secrets, promising safer medicines and stronger data protection.
articles.personality_title_fr: Twists à puce plate Light pour révéler des images cachées et protéger la santé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les scientifiques ont depuis longtemps étudié la «mainseté» ou la chiralité, ce qui signifie que certaines choses, comme nos mains ou certaines molécules, se présentent sous des formes d'image miroir qui ne peuvent pas être échangées. Cela compte beaucoup en biologie et en médecine car la version droite ou gauche d'une molécule peut changer son fonctionnement dans notre corps.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont créé une nouvelle puce plate à l'aide d'une surface spéciale appelée métasurface qui peut tordre la lumière de manière unique. Cette lumière tordue aide à révéler des images cachées à la vue normale et peut détecter la main de la main des molécules - révélant si elles sont à gauche ou à droite.

**Impact**
Cette percée pourrait rendre le chiffrement des données beaucoup plus sûr en cachant des informations dans des modèles de lumière torsadés. Il ouvre également la porte à de meilleurs biocapteurs qui identifient rapidement la maintenance des molécules, l'amélioration de la sécurité des médicaments et aidant à garantir que les médicaments fonctionnent comme prévu.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient d'affiner cette technologie pour le rendre pratique pour une utilisation quotidienne dans les domaines de la santé et de la sécurité. Ils espèrent développer des dispositifs qui peuvent facilement détecter la remise moléculaire et protéger les informations sensibles à l'aide de la lumière tordue.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Une nouvelle puce plate qui tord la lumière déverrouille des images cachées et des secrets moléculaires, des médicaments plus sûrs prometteurs et une protection des données plus forte.
articles.personality_title_es: Los giros de chips planos la luz para revelar imágenes ocultas y proteger la salud
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los científicos han estudiado durante mucho tiempo la "mano" o la quiralidad, lo que significa que algunas cosas, como nuestras manos o ciertas moléculas, vienen en formas de imagen espejo que no se pueden cambiar. Esto importa mucho en biología y medicina porque la versión derecha o izquierda de una molécula puede cambiar la forma en que funciona en nuestros cuerpos.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores crearon un nuevo chip plano con una superficie especial llamada MetaSurface que puede torcer la luz de maneras únicas. Esta luz retorcida ayuda a revelar imágenes ocultas a la vista normal y puede detectar la mano de las moléculas, diciendo si son izquierda o diestra.

**Impacto**
Este avance podría hacer que el cifrado de datos sea mucho más seguro ocultando información en patrones de luz retorcidos. También abre la puerta a mejores biosensores que identifican rápidamente la mano de las moléculas, mejorando la seguridad de los medicamentos y ayudando a garantizar que los medicamentos funcionen según lo previsto.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los científicos planean refinar esta tecnología para que sea práctico para el uso diario en los campos de salud y seguridad. Esperan desarrollar dispositivos que puedan detectar fácilmente la mano molecular y proteger la información confidencial utilizando la luz retorcida.

**Control de una oración**
Un nuevo chip plano que gira de luz está desbloqueando imágenes ocultas y secretos moleculares, prometiendo medicamentos más seguros y protección de datos más fuerte.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a delicate flat chip surface filled with tiny, intricately arranged spiral-shaped elements shifting subtly in size and orientation, glowing softly as beams of left- and right-handed twisted light gently spiral over it, revealing two hidden images—a stylized Australian cockatoo and the iconic Swiss Matterhorn—emerging like magical watermarks beneath the light, all rendered in natural, soft earth tones and muted blues against a simple, abstract background.

articles.title: Why broken crystals are stronger
articles.summary: Crystals may seem flawless, but deep inside they contain tiny structural imperfections that dramatically influence their strength and behavior. Researchers from The University of Osaka have used the sophisticated math of differential geometry to reveal how these defects—like dislocations and disclinations—interact in elegant, unified ways. Their findings could help scientists engineer tougher, smarter materials by intentionally leveraging these flaws rather than avoiding them.
articles.content:
Crystals are known far and wide for their beauty and elegance. But even though they may appear perfect on the outside, their microstructure can be quite complicated, making them difficult to model mathematically.

But there are people rising to the challenge. In an article published this month in Royal Society Open Science, researchers from The University of Osaka used differential geometry to provide a robust, rigorous, and unified description for the mechanics of crystals and their defects.

In an ideal crystal, each atom is arranged in a perfectly periodic pattern. However, most crystals, upon closer examination, are not perfect. They contain small defects in their structure -- a missing atom here, an extra bond there. These defects have important mechanical consequences -- they could be the starting point of a fracture, for example, or they could even be used to strengthen materials. Understanding defects and their phenomena is thus very important to researchers.

"Defects come in many forms," explains lead author of the study Shunsuke Kobayashi. "For example, there are so-called dislocations associated with the breaking of translational symmetry and disclinations associated with the breaking of rotational symmetry. Capturing all of these kinds of defects in a single mathematical theory is not straightforward."

Indeed, previous models have failed to reconcile the differences between dislocations and disclinations, suggesting that modifications to the theory are needed. New mathematical tools using the language of differential geometry proved to be exactly what the team needed to address these issues.

"Differential geometry provides a very elegant framework for describing these rich phenomena," says Ryuichi Tarumi, senior author. "Simple mathematical operations can be used to capture these effects, allowing us to focus on the similarities between seemingly disparate defects."

Using the formalism of Riemann-Cartan manifolds, the research team was able to elegantly encapsulate the topological properties of defects and rigorously prove the relationship between dislocations and disclinations; previously, only empirical observations existed, and their rigorous mathematical forms were a mystery. In addition, they were able to derive analytical expressions for the stress fields caused by these defects.

The team hopes that their geometric approach to describing the mechanics of crystals will eventually inspire scientists and engineers to design materials with specific properties by taking advantage of defects, such as the strengthening of materials that is seen with disclinations. In the meantime, these results are yet another example of how beauty in mathematics can help us understand beauty in nature.
articles.reasoning: This article highlights a scientific breakthrough in understanding crystal defects using advanced mathematics, which can lead to the engineering of stronger, smarter materials. Such progress in material science is positive and hopeful as it can have broad applications in technology and industry.
articles.personality_title: How broken crystals become stronger and smarter
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Crystals often look perfect to our eyes, but deep inside, they hide tiny imperfections in their structure. These little flaws have a big influence on how strong and flexible the crystals really are. Scientists have long struggled to understand exactly how these imperfections work together.

**What happened**
A team of researchers from The University of Osaka used advanced math, called differential geometry, to unlock the mystery of these crystal flaws. They found a unified way to describe how different types of defects interact inside crystals, turning what seemed like weaknesses into strengths.

**Impact**
This discovery could change how we design materials. Instead of trying to avoid imperfections, scientists can now think about using them to create tougher and smarter materials. This breakthrough opens new doors for industries that rely on strong materials, like electronics, construction, and more.

**What's next step**
Researchers will likely build on this mathematical framework to experiment with new materials, testing how to control and use crystal defects to their advantage. This could lead to innovative products that are both more durable and versatile.

**One-sentence takeaway**
By understanding and embracing tiny flaws inside crystals, scientists are finding ways to make stronger, smarter materials for the future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment les cristaux brisés deviennent plus forts et plus intelligents
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Les cristaux sont souvent parfaits pour nos yeux, mais au plus profond, ils cachent de minuscules imperfections dans leur structure. Ces petits défauts ont une grande influence sur la force et la flexible que les cristaux sont vraiment. Les scientifiques ont longtemps eu du mal à comprendre exactement comment ces imperfections fonctionnent ensemble.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Une équipe de chercheurs de l'Université d'Osaka a utilisé des mathématiques avancées, appelées géométrie différentielle, pour débloquer le mystère de ces défauts cristallins. Ils ont trouvé une façon unifiée de décrire comment différents types de défauts interagissent à l'intérieur des cristaux, transformant ce qui semblait être des faiblesses en forces.

**Impact**
Cette découverte pourrait changer la façon dont nous concevons les matériaux. Au lieu d'essayer d'éviter les imperfections, les scientifiques peuvent désormais penser à les utiliser pour créer des matériaux plus durs et plus intelligents. Cette percée ouvre de nouvelles portes aux industries qui reposent sur des matériaux solides, comme l'électronique, la construction, etc.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs s'appuieront probablement sur ce cadre mathématique pour expérimenter de nouveaux matériaux, testant comment contrôler et utiliser des défauts cristallins à leur avantage. Cela pourrait conduire à des produits innovants à la fois plus durables et polyvalents.

**à emporter à une phrase**
En comprenant et en embrassant de minuscules défauts à l'intérieur des cristaux, les scientifiques trouvent des moyens de fabriquer des matériaux plus forts et plus intelligents pour l'avenir.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo los cristales rotos se vuelven más fuertes e inteligentes
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Los cristales a menudo se ven perfectos para nuestros ojos, pero en el fondo, esconden pequeñas imperfecciones en su estructura. Estos pequeños defectos tienen una gran influencia en lo fuertes y flexibles que son realmente los cristales. Los científicos han luchado durante mucho tiempo para comprender exactamente cómo funcionan estas imperfecciones juntas.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de investigadores de la Universidad de Osaka usó matemáticas avanzadas, llamada geometría diferencial, para desbloquear el misterio de estos fallas de cristal. Encontraron una forma unificada de describir cómo los diferentes tipos de defectos interactúan dentro de los cristales, convirtiendo lo que parecía debilidades en fortalezas.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento podría cambiar la forma en que diseñamos materiales. En lugar de tratar de evitar las imperfecciones, los científicos ahora pueden pensar en usarlas para crear materiales más difíciles e inteligentes. Este avance abre nuevas puertas para industrias que dependen de materiales fuertes, como la electrónica, la construcción y más.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Es probable que los investigadores se basen en este marco matemático para experimentar con nuevos materiales, probando cómo controlar y usar defectos de cristal para su ventaja. Esto podría conducir a productos innovadores que son más duraderos y versátiles.

**Control de una oración**
Al comprender y adoptar pequeños defectos dentro de los cristales, los científicos están encontrando formas de hacer materiales más fuertes e inteligentes para el futuro.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a radiant crystal lattice glowing softly with intricate geometric patterns, where small graceful cracks and twists reveal elegant swirling curves and interconnected loops symbolizing dislocations and disclinations, set against a calm, neutral background that highlights the harmony between imperfection and strength using simple, natural colors.

articles.title: It’s not that you look—it’s when: The hidden power of eye contact
articles.summary: A groundbreaking study from Flinders University reveals that it's not just making eye contact that matters, but precisely when and how you do it. By studying interactions between humans and virtual partners, researchers discovered a powerful gaze sequence that makes people more likely to interpret a look as a call for help. Even more surprising: the same response pattern held true whether the "partner" was human or robot, offering insights into how our brains instinctively process social cues.
articles.content:
For the first time, a new study has revealed how and when we make eye contact -- not just the act itself -- plays a crucial role in how we understand and respond to others, including robots.

Led by cognitive neuroscientist Dr Nathan Caruana, researchers from the HAVIC Lab at Flinders University asked 137 participants to complete a block-building task with a virtual partner.

They discovered that the most effective way to signal a request was through a specific gaze sequence: looking at an object, making eye contact, then looking back at the same object. This timing made people most likely to interpret the gaze as a call for help.

Dr Caruana says that identifying these key patterns in eye contact offers new insights into how we process social cues in face-to-face interactions, paving the way for smarter, more human-centered technology.

"We found that it's not just how often someone looks at you, or if they look at you last in a sequence of eye movements but the context of their eye movements that makes that behavior appear communicative and relevant," says Dr Caruana, from the College of Education, Psychology and Social Work.

"And what's fascinating is that people responded the same way whether the gaze behavior is observed from a human or a robot.

"Our findings have helped to decode one of our most instinctive behaviors and how it can be used to build better connections whether you're talking to a teammate, a robot, or someone who communicates differently.

"It aligns with our earlier work showing that the human brain is broadly tuned to see and respond to social information and that humans are primed to effectively communicate and understand robots and virtual agents if they display the non-verbal gestures we are used to navigating in our everyday interactions with other people."

The authors say the research can directly inform how we build social robots and virtual assistants that are becoming ever more ubiquitous in our schools, workplaces and homes, while also having broader implications beyond tech.

"Understanding how eye contact works could improve non-verbal communication training in high-pressure settings like sports, defense, and noisy workplaces," says Dr Caruana.

"It could also support people who rely heavily on visual cues, such as those who are hearing-impaired or autistic."

The team is now expanding the research to explore other factors that shape how we interpret gaze, such as the duration of eye contact, repeated looks, and our beliefs about who or what we are interacting with (human, AI, or computer-controlled).

The HAVIC Lab is currently conducting several applied studies exploring how humans perceive and interact with social robots in various settings, including education and manufacturing.

"These subtle signals are the building blocks of social connection," says Dr Caruana.

"By understanding them better, we can create technologies and training that help people connect more clearly and confidently."

The HAVIC Lab is affiliated with the Flinders Institute for Mental Health and Wellbeing and a founding partner of the Flinders Autism Research Initiative.

Acknowledgements: Authors were supported by an Experimental Psychology Society small grant.
articles.reasoning: The article presents a scientific breakthrough in understanding eye contact and social cues, which has positive implications for improving human communication and the development of social robots and virtual assistants. It highlights potential benefits for people with communication challenges and advances in technology that foster better social connections.
articles.personality_title: When you look matters: the surprising power of timing in eye contact
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A new study from Flinders University has uncovered that eye contact is more than just looking—it’s about when and how you look. This research explores how our brains pick up on social signals, even when interacting with robots.

**What happened**
Researchers led by Dr. Nathan Caruana asked 137 people to work on a block-building task alongside a virtual partner. They found a special pattern of gaze—looking at an object and then at the partner—that strongly signals a request for help. This pattern worked the same way whether the partner was human or a robot.

**Impact**
This discovery opens the door to better understanding how we communicate non-verbally. It could help improve social robots and virtual assistants, making them more natural and easier to interact with. It also holds promise for people who struggle with communication, offering new ways to connect.

**What's next step**
The researchers plan to explore how this gaze sequence can be used in real-life settings and in technology design. The goal is to create smarter social devices that respond more naturally to human cues.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Timing your eye contact just right can make all the difference in being understood—by people and even robots alike.
articles.personality_title_fr: Lorsque vous regardez compte: la puissance surprenante du timing dans le contact visuel
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Une nouvelle étude de l'Université Flinders a découvert que le contact visuel est plus que simplement à la recherche - il s'agit de savoir quand et à quoi vous ressemblez. Cette recherche explore comment notre cerveau reprend les signaux sociaux, même lors de l'interaction avec les robots.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs dirigés par le Dr Nathan Caruana ont demandé à 137 personnes de travailler sur une tâche de construction de blocs aux côtés d'un partenaire virtuel. Ils ont trouvé un schéma spécial de regard - regardant dans un objet puis au partenaire - qui signale fortement une demande d'aide. Ce modèle a fonctionné de la même manière que le partenaire était humain ou un robot.

**Impact**
Cette découverte ouvre la porte pour mieux comprendre comment nous communiquons de manière non verbale. Cela pourrait aider à améliorer les robots sociaux et les assistants virtuels, ce qui les rend plus naturels et plus faciles à interagir. Il est également prometteur pour les personnes qui luttent avec la communication, offrant de nouvelles façons de se connecter.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d'explorer comment cette séquence de regard peut être utilisée dans des paramètres réels et dans la conception technologique. L'objectif est de créer des appareils sociaux plus intelligents qui réagissent plus naturellement aux signaux humains.

**à emporter à une phrase**
Timer votre contact visuel juste à droite peut faire toute la différence dans la compréhension - par les gens et même les robots.
articles.personality_title_es: Cuando miras importa: el sorprendente poder del tiempo en el contacto visual
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Un nuevo estudio de la Universidad de Flinders ha descubierto que el contacto visual es más que mirar, se trata de cuándo y cómo se ve. Esta investigación explora cómo nuestros cerebros se dan cuenta de las señales sociales, incluso cuando interactúan con los robots.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores dirigidos por el Dr. Nathan Caruana pidieron a 137 personas que trabajaran en una tarea de construcción de bloques junto con un socio virtual. Encontraron un patrón especial de mirada, a lo que respecta a un objeto y luego a la pareja, que indica fuertemente una solicitud de ayuda. Este patrón funcionó de la misma manera que la pareja era humana o un robot.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento abre la puerta para comprender mejor cómo nos comunicamos de manera no verbal. Podría ayudar a mejorar los robots sociales y los asistentes virtuales, haciéndolos más naturales y más fáciles de interactuar. También es prometedor para las personas que luchan con la comunicación, ofreciendo nuevas formas de conectarse.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Los investigadores planean explorar cómo esta secuencia de la mirada se puede usar en entornos de la vida real y en el diseño de tecnología. El objetivo es crear dispositivos sociales más inteligentes que respondan más naturalmente a las señales humanas.

**Control de una oración**
Cronometrar su contacto visual a la derecha puede marcar la diferencia al ser entendido, tanto para personas como de robots por igual.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of two abstract, softly glowing orbs connected by a flowing, rhythmic line of light that shifts gaze between a simple geometric block and back to the orbs, set against a calm, muted background in natural tones, symbolizing the subtle dance of eye contact and communication between humans and robots.

articles.title: Google tapped billions of mobile phones to detect quakes worldwide — and send alerts
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02278-3Study reveals how the tech behemoth is using the motions sensors on phones to expand quake warnings to more countries.
articles.content:
Technology giant Google harnessed motion sensors on more than two billion mobile phones between 2021 and 2024 to detect earthquakes, and then sent automated warnings to millions of people in 98 countries. In an analysis of the data, released in Science today1, Google’s scientists say that the technology captured more than 11,000 quakes and performed on par with standard seismometers. Earthquake researchers who were not involved with the experiment are impressed by the system’s performance, but argue that public officials would need access to more information about the proprietary technology before relying on it.

AI predicts how many earthquake aftershocks will strike — and their strength

Over the past few decades, earthquake alert systems using standard seismometers have been deployed in locations including Mexico, Japan and the US west coast. But in 2020, Google announced that it would build a crowd-sourced system to detect tremors at their earliest stages by tracking the collective shaking of Android phones. The results from the first three years of operation, released today, show that the technology works and has improved over time. On average, thousands of people are killed by earthquakes each year, and with the mobile-based alert system in place, the number of people who now have access to earthquake alerts has increased tenfold since 2019, says Google.

“It’s very impressive: most countries don’t have an earthquake early-warning system, and this can help provide that service,” says Allen Husker, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. But, Husker says, he would feel better if Google would provide independent scientists with more access to the data and algorithms.

When a large quake hits, Google sends an urgent ‘TakeAction’ message to Android phones.Credit: Google

Scientists at Google say they are being as transparent as they can be about how the system works and performs. Owing to privacy concerns, sharing raw data from users’ phones is a challenge, they told Nature, but the Science paper is designed to shed as much light as possible on how the system works.

“That really is the origin of this paper,” says Richard Allen, a seismologist at the University of California, Berkeley, and visiting faculty member at Google. “I hope the community will recognize that and appreciate that.”

Crowd-sourced detection

The Android Earthquake Alerts system relies on quantity, not quality: research-grade seismometers provide higher quality data, but Google is relying on the ubiquity of modern Android smart phones — which collect and report motion data by default, unless users opt out — to get around a lack of sensitivity in any given device. In addition to mapping out data from individual users to identify earthquake origins and strength, the Google team developed algorithms to analyse the collected signals, which contain regional differences due to geology and building construction, and account for how various phone models register motion.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant technological advancement where Google uses mobile phone sensors to detect earthquakes and send early warnings to millions globally, potentially saving many lives. This innovation expands earthquake alert access to many countries that previously lacked such systems, representing a positive development in public safety and disaster preparedness.
articles.personality_title: Google turns billions of phones into a global earthquake alarm system
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Google has found a clever way to use the motion sensors inside smartphones to help detect earthquakes. These sensors, originally meant for things like screen rotation, can actually sense the shaking of an earthquake. This new method aims to provide early warnings to more people around the world.

**What happened**
Between 2021 and 2024, Google used the motion sensors from over two billion phones to spot earthquakes. When the sensors detected shaking, automated alerts were sent to millions of people in 98 countries. A recent study showed this system caught over 11,000 quakes and worked just as well as traditional earthquake detectors.

**Impact**
This technology is a game-changer for public safety. It expands earthquake warnings to places that didn’t have access before, giving people crucial extra seconds to prepare or take cover. Experts in earthquake research are excited about how this approach can save lives and improve disaster readiness worldwide.

**What's next step**
Google and scientists will continue refining the technology to make alerts even faster and more accurate. The goal is to reach even more countries and help more communities stay safe from earthquakes in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Google’s smart use of phone sensors is turning billions of devices into a powerful global earthquake alert system, helping protect millions around the world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Google transforme des milliards de téléphones en un système mondial d'alarme de tremblement de terre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Context**
Google a trouvé une façon intelligente d'utiliser les capteurs de mouvement à l'intérieur des smartphones pour aider à détecter les tremblements de terre. Ces capteurs, à l'origine destinés à des choses comme la rotation d'écran, peuvent réellement sentir le tremblement de tremblement de terre. Cette nouvelle méthode vise à fournir des avertissements précoces à davantage de personnes dans le monde.

**ce qui s'est passé**
Entre 2021 et 2024, Google a utilisé les capteurs de mouvement de plus de deux milliards de téléphones pour repérer les tremblements de terre. Lorsque les capteurs ont détecté des tremblements, des alertes automatisées ont été envoyées à des millions de personnes dans 98 pays. Une étude récente a montré que ce système a attrapé plus de 11 000 tremblements de terre et a travaillé aussi bien que des détecteurs de tremblements de terre traditionnels.

**Impact**
Cette technologie change la donne pour la sécurité publique. Il élargit les avertissements des tremblements de terre à des endroits qui n’avaient pas accès auparavant, donnant aux gens des secondes supplémentaires cruciales pour se préparer ou se couvrir. Les experts de la recherche sur les tremblements de terre sont enthousiasmés par la façon dont cette approche peut sauver des vies et améliorer la préparation aux catastrophes dans le monde entier.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Google et les scientifiques continueront de raffiner la technologie pour rendre les alertes encore plus rapides et plus précises. L'objectif est d'atteindre encore plus de pays et d'aider davantage de communautés à rester à l'abri des tremblements de terre à l'avenir.

**à emporter à une phrase**
L'utilisation intelligente de Google des capteurs téléphoniques transforme des milliards d'appareils en un puissant système d'alerte de tremblement de terre, contribuant à protéger des millions à travers le monde.
articles.personality_title_es: Google convierte miles de millones de teléfonos en un sistema global de alarma de terremotos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**contexto**
Google ha encontrado una forma inteligente de usar los sensores de movimiento dentro de los teléfonos inteligentes para ayudar a detectar terremotos. Estos sensores, originalmente destinados a cosas como la rotación de la pantalla, en realidad pueden sentir el temblor de un terremoto. Este nuevo método tiene como objetivo proporcionar advertencias tempranas a más personas en todo el mundo.

**Qué pasó**
Entre 2021 y 2024, Google utilizó los sensores de movimiento de más de dos mil millones de teléfonos para detectar terremotos. Cuando los sensores detectaron sacudidas, se enviaron alertas automatizadas a millones de personas en 98 países. Un estudio reciente mostró que este sistema atrapó más de 11,000 terremotos y funcionó tan bien como detectores de terremotos tradicionales.

**Impacto**
Esta tecnología cambia el juego para la seguridad pública. Expande advertencias de terremotos a lugares que no tenían acceso antes, dando a las personas cruciales segundos adicionales para prepararse o cubrir. Los expertos en investigación de terremotos están entusiasmados con cómo este enfoque puede salvar vidas y mejorar la preparación para desastres en todo el mundo.

**¿Qué es el siguiente paso**?
Google y los científicos continuarán refinando la tecnología para hacer alertas aún más rápidas y precisas. El objetivo es llegar a aún más países y ayudar a más comunidades a mantenerse a salvo de los terremotos en el futuro.

**Control de una oración**
El uso inteligente de los sensores telefónicos de Google está convirtiendo miles de millones de dispositivos en un poderoso sistema global de alerta de terremotos, ayudando a proteger a millones de personas en todo el mundo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vast network of glowing, interconnected smartphones floating above a peaceful, stylized global map, with gentle, colorful vibrations radiating from their screens like ripples in water, symbolizing the worldwide detection of earthquakes through crowd-sourced motion sensing.
